title: TripAdvisor reviewers name the best museums in the world as NY's Egyptian artefacts triumph | Daily Mail Online
text:

A massive art museum that is home to an Egyptian stone temple, King Henry VIII’s field armour and a fascinating medieval sculpture hall has been named the best museum in the world by tourists.
New York City’s Metropolitan Museum of Art – the largest art museum in the US – edged top attractions in Paris and London for top spot in TripAdvisor’s travellers’ choice awards.
Home to some of the greatest artefacts, sculptures or paintings, these are the 10 most popular museums in the world based on TripAdvisor reviews from the last year.
1. Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York City)
More than six million people visited the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the last fiscal year (pictured: Egyptian Temple of Dendur)
With a collection spanning more than 5,000 years of world culture, the Metropolitan Museum of Art had a record 6.3million visitors in its last fiscal year.
Set on the edge of Central Park on Manhattan’s Museum Mile, its main building hosts dozens of exhibitions every year and remains one of the most visited art museums in the world.

Share this article Share The permanent medieval sculpture hall features sculptures, altarpieces, tapestries and furniture as old as 1300, and the Egyptian Temple of Dendur is a popular draw.
2. Musee d’Orsay (Paris)
Musee d’Orsay has the largest collection of impressionist and post-impressionist masterpieces (pictured: Bal du moulin de la Galette)
Housed in the former Gare d’Orsay railway station, Musee d’Orsay has the largest collection of impressionist and post-impressionist masterpieces in the world.
Located on the left bank of the Seine, it has mostly French art from 1848 to 1915, with paintings by Monet, Manet, Renoir and Van Gogh.
Current exhibitions include a gallery of photos snapped by female photographers between 1918 and 1945, and Splendour and Misery, the first major show on prostitution.
3. Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago, Illinois)
The lure of American Gothic (middle) by Grant Wood helped the Art Institute of Chicago crack the top 10 in TripAdvisor's rankings
TripAdvisor users named the Art Institute of Chicago the world’s best museum in 2014, and this year it has dropped to third place.
It houses more than 300,000 works of art, and was one of the Chicago landmarks featured in the film Ferris Bueller’s Day Off.
Paintings on display include American Gothic, by Grant Wood, and A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte, by Seurat.
4. Museo Nacional del Prado (Madrid)
Important works by Diego Velazquez (pictured: Las Meninas) and Francisco de Goya are displayed at Museo Nacional del Prado
Spain’s main national art museum boasts an art collection dating back to the 12th century, including important works by Diego Velazquez and Francisco de Goya.
Museo Nacional del Prado has a vast collection of works by Spanish artists, drawing about three million visitors a year.
Earlier this year the only Michelangelo sculpture to be found in Spain went on display in the museum’s Villanueva Building.
5. Musee du Louvre (Paris)
Known for its large crowds, the Louvre is the most visited museum in the world thanks to attractions such as the Mona Lisa
Despite being the most visited museum in the world, the Louvre was named the world’s fifth best museum by visitors.
Known for its massive queues, the art museum on the right bank of the Seine attracts more than nine million visitors a year.
Its incredible collection boasts the Mona Lisa, the Winged Victory of Samothrace and Venus de Milo.

2. Museo Nacional del Prado, Madrid

2. British Museum, London

6. State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace (St Petersburg, Russia)
Popular exhibits at the State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace include Michelangelo’s unfinished Crouching Boy
This museum in northwestern Russia has one of the largest collections of Western European Art in the world.
As St Petersburg’s most popular tourist attraction, it has more three million pieces in its collection, with the bulk of the collection displayed in the Winter Palace, the former official residence of the Romanov Tsars.
Its most popular exhibits include two masterpieces by Leonardo da Vinci – the Madonna Litta and the Benois Madonna – and Michelangelo’s unfinished Crouching Boy, which depicts a crouching boy in the nude.
7. National Gallery (London)
Paintings by Italian artists are displayed at the National Gallery in London, which is free of charge and open 361 days a year
Set in busy Trafalgar Square in central London, the National Gallery has one of the world’s greatest collections of paintings.
Paintings from the 13th to the 19th centuries are on display 361 days a year, free of charge, at the museum, which was founded in 1824.
Highlights include Whistlejacket by George Stubbs, The Baptism of Christ by Piero della Francesca, and Bathers at Asnieres by Georges Seurat.
8. The Rijksmuseum (Amsterdam)
Amsterdam's Rijksmuseum presents more than 8,000 objects in an international context and in chronological order
Amsterdam’s Rijksmuseum reopened in 2013 after a 10-year rebuild and renovation, allowing its collection to be presented in 80 galleries.
With more than 8,000 objects, the museum tells the story of 800 years of Dutch art and history, from the Middle Ages to Mondrian.
Spread over four floors, the collection, including paintings, drawings, photographs and porcelain, is presented in an international context and in chronological order.
9. Vasa Museum (Stockholm)
Stockholm's Vasa Museum is named after a warship that sank on its maiden voyage and was salvaged more than 300 years later
Located on the island of Djurgarden, the Vasa Museum is named for the Vasa, a warship that sank on its maiden voyage in 1628.
It remained below for surface for 333 years until it was rediscovered, salvaged and reconstructed over a number of years.
After Vasa was lifted from the seabed in 1959 it took a year and a half for it to be raised to the surface in stages. Today, it is exhibited with three lower masts steeped and rigged, as she would be stored in the winter.
10. National Museum of Anthropology (Mexico City)
Skeletons found at the Teotihuacan archaeological site are displayed at the National Museum of Anthropology in Mexico City
Mexico’s most popular museum houses one of the world’s largest collections of artefacts from pre-Hispanic Mayan civilisations to the Spanish conquest.
It has an umbrella roof supported by a single column, which represents a mythological tree and depicts eagles and jaguars, which were powerful symbols to natives.
Highlights include an Aztec calendar, a reconstructed eighth century Mayan tomb, and preserved skeletons.
FROM THE BEST MUSEUMS IN THE WORLD TO THE WEIRDEST... A visitor looks at plush toys that were donated to the Museum of Broken Relationships in Zagreb, Croatia
While the world’s best museums manages to attract millions of visitors every year, tourists are also flocking to some of the weirdest.
Here are some of the strangest museums in the world:
Icelandic Phallological Museum , Reykjavik: The people behind this museum say it is probably the only one in the world containing a collection of penises and penile parts belonging to land and sea mammals.
Museum of Broken Relationships , Zagreb: Dedicated to failed relationships, the exhibits include gifted or unwanted items from former lovers, including fluffy handcuffs, a wedding dress and plush toys.
Museum of Bad Art, Boston : It is billed as the world’s only museum dedicated to bad art, with more than 600 pieces in its collection.
Meguro Parasitological Museum , Tokyo: This museum is home to more than 300 varieties of parasites, with the most revolting being a 30ft tapeworm removed from an unsuspecting woman.
Currywurst Museum , Berlin: Visitors learn all about the culinary delight of currywurst at the first and only museum of its kind.
Avanos Hair Museum , Avanos, Turkey: More than 16,000 locks of hair have been donated by female visitors.
Museum of Funeral Carriages , Barcelona: This macabre museum has become a hit with visitors, who must report to the city’s Municipal Funeral Services before being guided to a basement exhibition.
